newsitem.title: MEXICO: Telmex's Slim says company ready to face rivals.
newsitem.headline: Telmex's Slim says company ready to face rivals.

text.p: Mexican telephone giant Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) is ready to face a host of new rivals that have started to compete for a share of the country's lucrative long-distance market, company chairman Carlos Slim said on Wednesday.

Telmex is so confident that it has already drawn up plans to attack the U.S. market at the same time that U.S. firms are competing for Mexican customers for the first time this year, Slim told a group of foreign correspondents.
"We carried out an unprecedented effort to get ready for the competition. They were the ones that weren't ready on time," Slim told reporters.
A loss in market share to rivals will pinch Telmex's 1997 long-distance revenues, which should be well below 1996 levels but only just below 1995 levels in dollar terms, Slim said.

Revenues in the country's overall long-distance market will probably stay at the same level in 1997 compared with 1996 as lower prices offset volume growth, he said, adding that he was reluctant to predict how the market would react.
Prices in Mexico's long-distance market have already fallen quickly in the past few months, and may fall further as new entrants to the market try to get established, he added.
